fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Equivalent condition for the existence of images

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal { C } be a category with pullbacks. Then \mathcal { C } has images iff for each morphism f \colon A \to B, the pullback functor f ^{*} \colon \mathsf { Sub } (B) \to \mathsf { Sub } (A) admits a left adjoint \exists _{f} \colon \mathsf { Sub } (A) \to \mathsf { Sub } (B).

By , the pullback functor f ^{*} \colon { \mathcal { C } _{/{ B }}} \to { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}} admits \Sigma _{f} \colon { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}} \to { \mathcal { C } _{/{ B }}} as a left adjoint.

Let g \colon B' \rightarrowtail B be an arbitrary object in \mathsf { Sub } (B). We need to construct a functor \mathsf { Img } \colon { \mathcal { C } _{/{ B }}} \to \mathsf { Sub } (B) so that each morphism f \to g in { \mathcal { C } _{/{ B }}} corresponds to a unique morphism \mathsf { Img } (f) \to g in \mathsf { Sub } (B).
Let f \to g be an arbitrary morphism in { \mathcal { C } _{/{ B }}}. Then this corresponds to a unique morphism \mathsf {id} _{ A } \to f ^{*} (g) as follows:

This then corresponds to a unique morphism \exists _{f}( \mathsf {id} _{ A } ) \to g under the adjunction \exists _{f} \dashv f ^{*}. Thus, we define \mathsf { Img } by the assignment f \mapsto \exists _{f}( \mathsf {id} _{ A } ). This assignment can be trivially extended to a functor: since the category \mathsf { Sub } (B) is a preorder, every morphism f \to f' in { \mathcal { C } _{/{ B }}} has to be mapped to the unique morphism \mathsf { Img } (f) \to \mathsf { Img } (f') in \mathsf { Sub } (B). This morphism must exist. Indeed, it is the lifting of \mathsf { Img } (f) against \varepsilon _{ \mathsf { Img } (f')} depicted in the following diagram.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We can now extract the components of the unit and the counit from this correspondence.

The identity morphism \mathsf {id} \colon \mathsf { Img } (f) \to \mathsf { Img } (f) is, by definition, the identity morphism \mathsf {id} \colon \exists _{f}( \mathsf {id} _{ A } ) \to \mathsf { Img } (f), which corresponds to the unit \eta _{ \mathsf {id} _{ A } } \colon \mathsf {id} _{ A } \to f ^{*} ( \mathsf { Img } (f)) of the adjunction \exists _{f} \dashv f ^{*}.

Then since \mathsf { Img } (f) is monic, \eta _{ \mathsf {id} _{ A } } corresponds to a unique morphism \varepsilon _{ \mathsf { Img } (f)} \eta _{ \mathsf {id} _{ A } } \colon f \to \mathsf { Img } (f), where \varepsilon is the counit of the adjunction \Sigma _{f} \dashv f ^{*}. fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If \mathcal { C } has images, then we may define \exists _{f} \colon \mathsf { Sub } (A) \to \mathsf { Sub } (B) as the following composite:
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \mathsf { Sub } (A) \hookrightarrow { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}} \xrightarrow { \Sigma _{f} } { \mathcal { C } _{/{ B }}} \xrightarrow { \mathsf { Img } } \mathsf { Sub } (B)
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let i_{A} \colon \mathsf { Sub } (A) \hookrightarrow { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}} and i_{B} \colon \mathsf { Sub } (B) \hookrightarrow { \mathcal { C } _{/{ B }}} be the inclusion functors. Note that
Since f ^{*} i_{B} \cong i_{A} f ^{*} by construction, we have

Let \eta and \varepsilon be the unit and counit of this adjunction respectively. Since \mathsf { Sub } (A) is a full subcategory of { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}}, there is a natural isomorphism \iota \colon \mathsf {id} _{ { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}} } \stackrel { \sim }{ \smash { \longrightarrow } \rule {0pt}{0.4ex}} i_{A}. Then we can define \eta ' as follows:
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \eta ' := \mathsf {id} _{ { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}} } \xrightarrow { \eta } i_{A} f ^{*} \mathsf { Img } \Sigma _{f} \xrightarrow { \iota _{ f ^{*} \mathsf { Img } \Sigma _{f}} } f ^{*} \mathsf { Img } \Sigma _{f} \xrightarrow { f ^{*} \mathsf { Img } \Sigma _{f}( \iota ) } f ^{*} \mathsf { Img } \Sigma _{f}i_{A}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then \eta ' and \varepsilon form the unit and counit of the adjunction \mathsf { Img } \Sigma _{f}i_{A} \dashv f ^{*}.

A category \mathcal { C } is said to have images if the inclusion functor \mathsf { Sub } (A) \hookrightarrow { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}} admits a left adjoint \mathsf { Img } \colon { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}} \to \mathsf { Sub } (A) for all objects A \in \mathcal { C }.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Slice comparison functor of a locally cartesian category admits a right adjoint

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A category \mathcal { C } is locally cartesian iff for all morphisms f of \mathcal { C }, the functor \Sigma _{f} constructed in admits a right adjoint f ^{*}. Moreover, f ^{*} is (isomorphic to) the pullback functor.
By , locally cartesian categories are precisely those categories with pullbacks.
Suppose that \Sigma _{f} \dashv f ^{*} for any f. We show that the following diagram

is a pullback, where \varepsilon _{g} is the counit of the adjunction. Note that since f \circ f ^{*} (g) = \Sigma _{f}( f ^{*} (g)) by construction, the component \varepsilon _{g} makes the diagram commute.
Let h' \colon C \to A and h \colon C \to B' be morphisms such that fh' = gh.
Note that h is a morphism h \colon \Sigma _{f}(h') \to g in { \mathcal { C } _{/{ B }}}. Thus, it corresponds to a unique morphism h ^{ \dag } \colon h' \to f ^{*} (g) under the adjunction.

The transpose of h ^{ \dag } can be computed as \varepsilon _{g} \circ \Sigma _{f}(h ^{ \dag } ). Since \Sigma _{f} is the identity on morphisms, we have (h ^{ \dag } ) ^{ \dag } = \varepsilon _{g} \circ \Sigma _{f}(h ^{ \dag } ) = \varepsilon _{g} \circ h ^{ \dag } = h Thus, the top triangle also commutes.
Suppose that \mathcal { C } has pullbacks. Then we can take f ^{*} to be the pullback functor. It remains to check that \Sigma _{f} \dashv f ^{*}.
By construction, \varepsilon _{ \Sigma _{f}} \eta = \mathsf {id} _{ \Sigma _{f} }. Thus, it remains to verify the other triangle equality.

Let g \in { \mathcal { C } _{/{ B }}} be an object. We need to show that f ^{*} ( \varepsilon _{g}) \eta _{ f ^{*} (g)} = \mathsf {id} _{ f ^{*} (g) }. Note that f ^{*} (g) f ^{*} ( \varepsilon _{g}) \eta _{ f ^{*} (g)} = f ^{*} (g) by the construction of f ^{*}. Moreover, we also have the following equation.
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {align*} \varepsilon _{g} f ^{*} ( \varepsilon _{g}) \eta _{ f ^{*} (g)} &= \varepsilon _{g} \varepsilon _{f \circ f ^{*} (g)} \eta _{ f ^{*} (g)} && \text {by the construction of } f ^{*} \\ &= \varepsilon _{g} \mathsf {id} && \text {by the construction of } \eta \\ &= \varepsilon _{g} \end {align*}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Thus, f ^{*} ( \varepsilon _{g}) \eta _{ f ^{*} (g)} corresponds to the same cone over f and g as \mathsf {id} _{ f ^{*} (g) }. Then uniqueness implies that they are equal.

Then by , A_{1} \cap ( \mathord { \hspace {1pt} \text {--} \hspace {1pt}} ) can be described as the composite \mathsf { Sub } (A) \xrightarrow { m ^{*} } \mathsf { Sub } (A_{1}) \xrightarrow { \exists _{m} } \mathsf { Sub } (A). fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {align*} A_{1} \cap (A_{2} \cup A_{3}) & \cong \exists _{m} m ^{*} (A_{2} \cup A_{3}) && \text {$ m ^{*} $ preserves finite unions} \\ & \cong \exists _{m}( m ^{*} (A_{2}) \cup m ^{*} (A_{3})) && \text {left adjoint preserves finite unions} \\ & \cong \exists _{m} m ^{*} (A_{2}) \cup \exists _{m} m ^{*} (A_{3}) \\ & \cong (A_{1} \cap A_{2}) \cup (A_{1} \cap A_{3}) \end {align*}

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Union as a pushout of intersection

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal { C } be a coherent category and A_{1} and A_{2} be subobjects of A. Then the following square is both a pullback and a pushout in \mathcal { C }.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = {A_{1} \cap A_{2}}, ne = {A_{2}}, sw = {A_{1}}, se = {A_{1} \cup A_{2}}, north = {i_{2}}, north/style = {>->}, west = {i_{1}}, west/style = {>->}, south = {u_{1}}, south/style = {>->}, east = {u_{2}}, east/style = {>->}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: where the i's and the u's are the product projections and coproduct injections in \mathsf { Sub } (A) respectively.

The diagram commutes since \mathsf { Sub } (A) is a preorder: any two morphisms A_{1} \cap A_{2} \rightrightarrows A_{1} \cup A_{2} in \mathsf { Sub } (A) are equal. Moreover, this diagram is a pullback in \mathsf { Sub } (A) as the pullback of u_{2} along u_{1} is just the largest subobject contained in both A_{1} and A_{2}, i.e., the intersection. Then since both the inclusion \mathsf { Sub } (A) \hookrightarrow { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}} (as a right adjoint) and the forgetful functor { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}} \to \mathcal { C } preserve pullbacks, the square is a pullback in \mathcal { C }.

Note that the forgetful functor { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}} \to \mathcal { C } preserves arbitrary colimits, but the inclusion functor does not necessarily preserve them, so the same strategy does not work for pushout.

Let f \colon A_{1} \to B and g \colon A_{2} \to B be morphisms in \mathcal { C } such that fi_{1} = gi_{2}. Consider the joint morphisms (f,u_{1}) \colon A_{1} \rightarrowtail B \times (A_{1} \cup A_{2}) and (g,u_{2}) \colon A_{2} \rightarrowtail B \times (A_{1} \cup A_{2}), which are monic because u_{1} and u_{2} are. Let (m,n) \colon U \rightarrowtail B \times (A_{1} \cup A_{2}) be the union of (f,u_{1}) and (g,u_{2}) in \mathsf { Sub } (B \times (A_{1} \cup A_{2})). We show that n is an isomorphism.

The functor \exists _{ \pi _{2}} \colon \mathsf { Sub } (B \times (A_{1} \cup A_{2})) \to \mathsf { Sub } (A_{1} \cup A_{2}) constructed in , as a left adjoint, preserves arbitrary unions. Let us consider the image of n:
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {align*} \exists _{ \pi _{2}}(m, n) & \cong \mathsf { Img } ( \pi _{2}(m,n)) \\ & \cong \mathsf { Img } (n) \\ & \cong \exists _{ \pi _{2}}((f,u_{1}) \cup (g,u_{2})) \\ & \cong \exists _{ \pi _{2}}(f,u_{1}) \cup \exists _{ \pi _{2}}(g,u_{2}) \\ & \cong \mathsf { Img } ( \pi _{2}(f,u_{1})) \cup \mathsf { Img } ( \pi _{2}(g,u_{2})) \\ & \cong u_{1} \cup u_{2} \\ & \cong \mathsf {id} _{ A_{1} \cup A_{2} } \end {align*}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Thus, if n is monic then \mathsf { Img } (n) \cong n \cong \mathsf {id} _{ A_{1} \cup A_{2} }, i.e., n is the whole of A_{1} \cup A_{2}, so it is an isomorphism. By the construction of \exists _{f}, this is equivalent to showing the following isomorphism. \mathsf { Img } (f \circ (A' \cap f ^{*} (B'))) \cong \mathsf { Img } (f \circ A') \cap B'
Form the following diagram, where the front, left, and right faces are pullbacks.

By the pasting lemma, the back square is also a pullback. Then since covers are stable under pullback in a regular category, the north edge of the back square is also a cover. The diagonal of the right face is \mathsf { Img } (f \circ A') \cap B', which forms a cover-mono factorization of the composite f \circ (A' \cap f ^{*} (B')).
